subject: Re: [junit] estimating effort for Junit
msgSnippet: ... Are you adding tests to existing code or starting to test-drive new features? If you are adding tests to existing code, then the cost of adding tests
messageBody:
svaddiparti wrote:

> Can somebody help me in a methodology for estimating the effort
> required for developing JUNIT test cases/classes for a complex
> websphere based application.
>
> appreciate you can share some ideas as to how to go about.

Are you adding tests to existing code or starting to test-drive new
features?

If you are adding tests to existing code, then the cost of adding tests
depends directly on the degree of coupling in the application, and
without looking at an application, it's tough to say. There is no
published generic methodology (like COCOMO) for estimating the effort of
adding tests that I'm aware of.

The best I can suggest is to conduct some experiments. See how much of
the system you can test in a week. This will give you a rough idea, at
any rate. Even then, it is possible that you'll find a refactoring in
week three that makes the rest of the system much, much easier to test.
That is more likely than the reverse -- in other words, the cost of
testing a system tends to go down as you cover more of the system with
tests. (This is a slight simplification, but it's true enough for you at
this moment.)
